The Secretary, Commonwealth Communications Council, Halifax House, Strand, W.C. 2. Dear Sir, We refer to your letter P.416 of 25 th June, relating to the proposed establishment of telegraphic communication in Qatar. We have been in communication with our Divisional Manager in the Persian Gulf and have ascertained that between 1935 and 1942 our Bahrein wireless station was in telegraphic communication intermittently with Dohah (Qatar), a service which was undertaken at the request of the Anglo-Persian Oil Company. This service was discontinued in December 1942. In March 1944 at the request of Petroleum Concessions Ltd. it was arranged for Bahrein to exchange radiotelephone calls with their launch when visiting the Trucial Coast and Qatar. In order to assist Petroleum Concessions, the above mentioned telephone service was extended occas^lanally # to Dukhan (Qatar). We are informed that Petroleum Concessions much appreciated the service furnished and are likely to request this Company to make the service permanent. Before we discuss further the establishment by the Company of a wireless telegraph station in Qatar, we think that it would be advantageous to ascertain the status of Petroleum Concessions as regards telecommunications in Qatar. We are informed that the terms of their Concession in Qatar, Petroleum Concessions ‘’may construct, maintain,and operate telegraph and telephone installations and their lines and wireless station s”. Further, we are advised that they will normally maintain a wireless transmitter and a receiving set at their main camp, apart from radiotelephone communication with launches at sea. In view of the above, v/e should be glad if you would •kindly let us know if you wish us to contact Petroleum | Concessions Ltd., on the subject and if the Political | Resident in the Persian Gulf could furnish this Company with some information of conditions, business activities, and possibilities of obtaining telegraph traffic in Qatar. Also whether accommodation would be available for the staff and offices at any point in Qatar where it would beconsidered desirable that a wireless installation should be established. Yours truly. (signed) E.K. JENKINS. mods.abstract: The file concerns discussions on the proposed opening of a telegraph office in Qatar.The file contains correspondence between: the Government of India; the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf; the Commonwealth Communications Council; the India Office; and Cable and Wireless Limited.
